title: 109_hr238
content: The "Educational Empowerment Act" designates educational empowerment zones under the Internal Revenue Code of 1986. The "Educational Empowerment Act" designates up to 30 nominated areas as educational empowerment zones, defined as areas nominated by local governments and states and jointly designated by the Secretaries of Health and Human Services and Education. The "Educational Empowerment Act" allows for the designation of up to 30 nominated areas as educational empowerment zones based on specific criteria. The Secretaries concerned will prescribe regulations for these designations. The Secretaries concerned will prescribe regulations for nominating and evaluating educational empowerment zones within a 24-month period. The Secretaries concerned will prescribe regulations for nominating and evaluating educational empowerment zones within a 24-month period, starting on the first day of the first month following the month in which the regulations are prescribed. Procedural rules must be followed for the designation of nominated areas as educational empowerment zones, including submitting nominations in the required manner and form with accurate information. The nomination process for Indian reservations under this subchapter treats the reservation governing body as both the State and local governments for nominated areas. Designations as educational empowerment zones are effective until December 31, 2008, or until revoked by the Secretaries concerned. The Secretary of Commerce may designate areas based on eligibility requirements. The Secretary of Commerce may designate an educational empowerment zone if the area meets specific requirements, including being within the jurisdiction of local governments, having a continuous boundary, and not including another empowerment zone. The nominated area must also meet eligibility requirements set by the State and local governments. The Secretary of Education may certify a nominated area as an educational empowerment zone if it meets specified conditions, considering factors like low-income families, high dropout rates, teen pregnancy, and large class sizes. If an area is designated both as an educational empowerment zone and an enterprise community, both designations will be fully effective. The text discusses the certification of an area as an educational empowerment zone based on specific conditions. It also mentions the application of rules similar to those in section 1393 for this purpose. Additionally, a clerical amendment is made to the table of subchapters for chapter 1. SEC. 3. CREDIT FOR DONATIONS TO SCHOOL DISTRICTS IN EDUCATIONAL EMPOWERMENT ZONES. Amends the Internal Revenue Code to allow for contributions to school districts in educational empowerment zones. The tax code allows a credit for qualified educational empowerment zone contributions made by taxpayers to school districts in designated zones. The maximum credit is $2,000 for individuals and $10,000 for other taxpayers. Qualified contributions are cash donations that would be deductible under section 170 if not for certain restrictions. The tax code allows a credit for qualified educational empowerment zone contributions made by taxpayers to school districts in designated zones. Contributions must be used for purposes like hiring new teachers, increasing teacher salaries, or training teachers. No double benefit deduction is allowed, and taxpayers must elect to apply this section for a taxable year. The credit cannot exceed the excess of the regular tax for the year reduced by other credits. The tax code allows a credit for qualified educational empowerment zone contributions made by taxpayers to school districts in designated zones. Contributions must be used for purposes like hiring new teachers, increasing teacher salaries, or training teachers. The credit cannot exceed the excess of the regular tax for the year reduced by other credits. The tax code allows a credit for educational empowerment zone contributions to school districts. The amendments apply to taxable years after December 31, 2005. Additionally, a new section on loan forgiveness for mathematics and science teachers is added to the Higher Education Act of 1965. The purpose of this section is to encourage individuals to enter and remain in teaching mathematics, science, and related fields. The Secretary will repay loans for new borrowers who have worked as full-time teachers for 3 years in an educational empowerment zone and are fully qualified teachers. The Revenue Code of 1986 outlines criteria for loan repayment for fully qualified teachers not in default on a loan. Repayment is on a first-come, first-served basis, with priority given to previous recipients. The Secretary has the authority to establish necessary regulations for this program. The Secretary may repay up to 80% of qualifying loans after 3 years of service, with additional repayments in the following years, not exceeding $10,000 in total. No refunding of loans is allowed under this section. The Secretary will repay a portion of the loan and the corresponding interest accrued for each year. Borrowers cannot receive benefits from both this section and another specified section. The Secretary will repay eligible lenders the aggregate amount of loans subject to repayment. Eligible individuals must apply for loan repayment. Each eligible individual must submit a complete application to the Secretary for loan repayment after completing the required years of qualifying employment. The application must demonstrate State certification for teaching in a public elementary or secondary school. To qualify for loan repayment, an individual must be a certified teacher or pass the State teacher licensing exam. For elementary school, a bachelor's degree and proficiency in various subjects are required. For middle or secondary school, a bachelor's degree and high competency in all teaching subjects are necessary. The program requires teachers to demonstrate high performance on academic tests or completion of an academic major in the subject areas they teach. The Secretary will conduct a national evaluation of the program's impact on individuals encouraged by it. Evaluation will be awarded competitively. The program under this section encourages individuals to pursue teaching careers in mathematics, science, or related fields. The evaluation includes determining the number of individuals remaining in teaching as a result, identifying barriers to effectiveness, assessing cost-effectiveness, and tracking the number of years of participation. Interim and final evaluation reports will be submitted to the President and Congress. The evaluation under this section aims to assess the impact of the program on individuals pursuing teaching careers in mathematics, science, or related fields. The final report is due by January 1, 2008.
